title: Vanilla Forums Xenforo password splitHash Unserialize Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

profile.name: Vanilla
profile.about: Vanilla is a powerfully simple discussion forum you can easily customize to make as unique as your community.

activities.message:
Post exploitation, it may look something like this:

```
mysql> select Name, Password, Email, HashMethod from GDN_User where HashMethod="Xenforo";
+----------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+------------+
| Name                             | Password                                                       | Email                                         | HashMethod |
+----------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+------------+
| jxupdgqeydfyewmrzvcnpyeqoyvuvsou | O:12:"ProxyRequest":1:{s:9:"CookieJar";s:14:"conf/.htaccess";} | jxupdgqeydfyewmrzvcnpyeqoyvuvsou@srcincite.io | Xenforo    |
| tafivppinffznsighlftzriwkftjfqzw | O:12:"ProxyRequest":1:{s:9:"CookieJar";s:14:"conf/.htaccess";} | tafivppinffznsighlftzriwkftjfqzw@srcincite.io | Xenforo    |
+----------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+------------+
2 rows in set (0.00 sec)
```

Hi there. Your report has been assigned to a developer who  will provide a feedback shortly.
Thank you.

This has been triaged.
Thank you.
Hi, thanks for the offer, however I can demonstrate rce with this. Would this up the bounty?

I scored it as an RCE, but with an Attack Complexity of 'High' (a number of factors can thwart the phar exploit / second step) and a Privileges Required of 'High' (admin). That brings the score to 8.0, or High.

Actually, I disagree because the second step doesn't require any additional privileges, etc and it's just as high impact as, say [410237](https://hackerone.com/reports/410237). Here is my RCE PoC. Can you adjust the bounty please?

> An authenticated admin user can inject an unserializable password in a another users account.

Are you saying you can do this step without administrator permissions?

Lowering the privileges required means ALL steps may be completed at that level.

No, I mean the additional second step also needs admin privileges but all the primitives exist to get full, reliable rce at that same privilege level. Just because there is a second step, doesn't mean the impact is any different to [410237](https://hackerone.com/reports/410237) for example, hence my rce poc.

Impact is only part of the CVSS calculation. Are you able to view my calculation and tell me which criteria's setting you find to be misrepresented? I'm not suggesting the impact is different than other RCE vulnerabilities, I'm simply acknowledging there are higher prerequisites. The standard CVSS calculation takes that into account and it diminishes the severity.
I canâ€™t see your CVSS score, but yes, if you mark it like that then it makes sense.
Hey @linc, hows the patch looking for this? Is it rolled out?
It is, thanks for the reminder.

summaries.content: An attacking admin user can inject an unserializable password in a another users account. Later when attempting a login with that user, the attacker can trigger a call to an unserialize in the splitHash function. By using a custom pop chain to write into the constants.php file, an attacker can leverage this to gain remote code execution.
